data.title: Cannot read property 'scheme' of undefined
data.body:
Got this by running "out of source" with latest clicking through some TS files of the workbench (within the vs/workbench/api folder):

```
Cannot read property 'scheme' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'scheme' of undefined
    at TypeScriptServiceClient.asAbsolutePath (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/extensions/typescript/out/typescriptServiceClient.js:211:21)
    at BufferSyncSupport.onDidRemoveDocument (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/extensions/typescript/out/features/bufferSyncSupport.js:110:36)
    at CallbackList.invoke (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/base/common/callbackList.js:57:43)
    at Emitter.fire (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/base/common/event.js:84:40)
    at ExtHostModelService._acceptModelRemoved (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostDocuments.js:157:51)
    at ExtHostThreadService.AbstractThreadService.handle (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/platform/thread/common/abstractThreadService.js:72:27)
    at invokeHandler (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/platform/extensions/common/ipcRemoteCom.js:127:53)
    at receiveOneMessage (/Users/bpasero/Development/Microsoft/monaco/out/vs/platform/extensions/common/ipcRemoteCom.js:84:36)
    at doNTCallback0 (node.js:443:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:372:13)
```

data.title: tsd and typings different?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11 stable, 0.10.12 alpha
- OS Version:Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go through the Node.js runtime walkthrough (/docs/runtimes/nodejs.md) to "adding a jsconfig.json file" step.
2. After adding jsconfig.json and restarting VS Code, try to get IntelliSense on `routes`. 

No Express.Router specific IntelliSense comes up.  This should be provided by:
    var routes = require('./routes/index');

This was initially reported by a customer through DocFeedback verbatim.

data.title: Selecting a line when file is auto-updating causes to scroll down near to the end of file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Something outside is writting to the file, and the changes are auto-updated by VSCode (in my case: my app is writting something to the log file every 1-2 seconds);
2. Start selecting a line in this file when VSCode adds new lines.

data.title: [snippets] Allow snippets where the prefix ends with =

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create the JavaScript snippets below

``` json
    "var statement": {
        "prefix": "v",
        "body": [
            "var ${1:name}"
        ]
    },
    "var assignment": {
        "prefix": "v=",
        "body": [
            "var ${1:name} = ${2:value}"
        ]
    }
```
1. Create a new file with the language set to `JavaScript`
2. Type `v` then TAB and note that the `var statement` snippet expands
3. Type `v=` then TAB and note that the `var assignment` snippet DOES NOT expand

data.title: Should JavaScript snippets automatically be made available to other JavaScript based languages (TypeScript, JavaScript React)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new JavaScript snippet, for example: 

``` json
{
    "console.log": {
        "prefix": "cl",
        "body": [
            "console.log('${1:arg}', ${1:arg});"
        ]
    }
}
```

2) If you create a new file with the language set to `JavaScript`, enter `cl` and press tab, the snippet will expand.

3) If you create a new file with the language set to `TypeScript`, the`cl` snippet is not available.

The current solution is to re-implement the snippet in all of the JavaScript based languages but that means duplicating the snippet for JavaScript, JavaScript React, TypeScript and TypeScript React. This makes it difficult to build up a large body of JavaScript snippets.

Should JavaScript snippets automatically be made available to other JavaScript based languages?

data.title: Add support for a bunch of zsh configuration files
data.body:
There are a bunch of zsh counterparts to bash's login/logout scripts. These are:
- `zshrc` (replaces `bashrc`)
- `zprofile` (replaces `bash_profile`)
- `zlogin` (replaces `bash_login`)
- `zlogout` (replaces `bash_logout`)
- `zshenv` (replaces `BASH_ENV` variable)

(For more information, see [this link](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Zsh#Configuration_files) on the Arch Linux wiki describing it in detail.)

This pull request adds these file extensions to the shell grammar, so they'll get syntax highlighting in VSCode.

data.title: add emmet support for .ejs files
Markdown shows stylesheet with preview, but not with the compiled files?

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body: Is there a(n easy) way to get the preview to become the compiled file, which would include the styling? Following the tutorial just creates the html (stub, since it's not a full page), and looking at the marked github page gives precious little info regarding how to include a stylesheet in the compiled file, except for a few items from 2013 (found via a Google search).

data.title: Constantly updating file runs git and causes PC to freeze

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 0.10.8
  Commit db71ac615ddf9f33b133ff2536f5d33a77d4774e
  Date 2016-02-05T10:00:07.223Z
  Shell 0.35.6
  Renderer 45.0.2454.85
  Node 4.1.1
- OS Version: 
  Ubuntu 15.10 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Setup a repository for git
2. Add a file, push it and open in git view
3. External program appends it (log) very quickly

It can be averted if I added the file in .gitignore. Still its a valid concern as I didn't expect VSCode to run git multiple times while it is being updated. The numerous git processes freeze the PC. There should be a timeout/backoff if too many git operations are run.

data.title: The type or namespace name `Forms' does not exist in the namespace `System.Windows'. Are you missing `System.Windows.Forms' assembly reference?

WinHello.cs(2,22): error CS0234: The type or namespace name `Forms' does not exist in the namespace`System.Windows'. Are you missing `System.Windows.Forms' assembly reference?
WinHello.cs(4,27): error CS0246: The type or namespace name`Form' could not be found. Are you missing an assembly reference?
Compilation failed: 2 error(s), 0 warnings

Here is a link to the sample code that you provided on your website.
http://www.mono-project.com/docs/getting-started/mono-basics/

data.title: Introduce a setting to configure display of hover widget

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 10.10.11
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.3

I am not able to find any setting which allows me to globally disable automatic tooltips generated by plugin `HoverProvider` implementations. I prefer to see `HoverProvider` information only when a modifier key is pressed (i.e. peek definition). I find automatic tooltips distracting, and there are also some [performance implications](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/257) depending on how plugins gather information.

Feature Request: Need a Git Commit command in the Command Palette
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Command Palette 
2. Search for `commit`
3. Notice that no `Git: Commit` command is available

I realize that the `CONTROL + SHIFT + G` shortcut is available, but in my opinion, for completeness, we should have a `Git: Commit` command in the Command Palette.

Cheers,
Trevor Sullivan
Microsoft MVP: PowerShell

data.title: Rename and fine all references of Typescript's string literal values
data.body:
Type script [string literals](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/5185) allow to have a code such as 

```
//interfaces.d.ts
type Options = "option 1 " | "option 2" 

//file.ts
let myOption: Options = "option 1" // "option 3" will give us an error, right in the IDE.
```

It would be nice to be able to rename and find all references of a specific value. e.g. find/rename all occurrences of "option 1". Currently we can only find the references of the type itself.

data.title: Settings in tsconfig.json file not being applied if tsconfig.json is in a subdirectory rather than root
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Place a tsconfig.json file in a subdirectory rather than in root (e.g. /src/tsconfig.json)
2. Ensure tsconfig.json contains "experimentalDecorators": true
3. Create a TypeScript file (under /src) that uses decorators
4. Visual Studio Code incorrectly displays an error regarding "Experimental support for decorators..."
5. If the tsconfig.json is moved to the root directory (and VS Code is then restarted) the error is no longer displayed

data.title: wrappingColumn
data.body:
there should be some way to disable wrapping?
i can set to zero to wrap automatically...
i should be able to set to **-1** to disable?
and i CAN! it is just that the description does not mention this:

> Controls after how many characters the editor will wrap to the next line. Setting this to 0 turns on viewport width wrapping

thanks

data.title: story for pulling in remote origin topic branch that already exists into local repo
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: win10 10586.164

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open folder containing clone of remote origin master
2. click on git branch status area in bottom left corner, or enter ctrl+p or f1+>Git: Checkout, and enter name of remote origin branch you want to local copy to reference.  the git ouput window shows "git checkout -q -b someTopicBranch" and "git fetch" were executed.
3.  folder doesn't contain copy of remote origin topic branch so from command line enter "git.exe config -l --local" where you'll see that branch.someTopicBranch.remote/.merge entries are not present
4.  from command line enter "git branch -u origin/someTopicBranch" or "git branch --set-upstream-to=someTopicBranch" to update local config to contain branch.someTopicBranch.remote/.merge entries
5.  from vscode you can now use git | ... | pull == "git pull" to retrieve the contents of the remote origin someTopicBranch that already existed

My thinking is that steps 3 thru 5 should be automated for you in case where you are not looking to create new topic branch and optionally later push it into remote origin but rather create local repo topic branch into which you sync the details of remote origin copy of topic branch that already exists.
